text: The elm cultivar Ulmus × hollandica 'Bea Schwarz' was cloned (as No. 62) at Wageningen in the Netherlands, by the elm disease committee, ostensibly from a selection of Ulmus minor found in France in 1939. However, specimens of the tree grown in the UK and the United States are treated as Ulmus × hollandica (after Fontaine ). ==Description== The tree was considered of poor growth and shape.Photograph of free-standing 'Bea Schwarz' elm, . ==Pests and diseases== Moderately resistant to Dutch elm disease, and more resistant to Coral Spot fungus Nectria cinnabarina than its forebear 'Christine Buisman'. ==Cultivation== Commercial production was discontinued soon after its release in 1948.Went, J. C. (1954). Tijschr. Plantenziekten 60: 109-127, 1954. Nevertheless, its moderate resistance to Dutch elm disease saw it, or its selfed progeny, successfully used in later Dutch hybridizations, notably 'Nanguen' = . File:Bea Schwarz-iepen bij de Sloterplas.jpg|'Bea Schwarz' on the left with later replacements on the right. Noordzijde, Sloterplas, Amsterdam, 2012. ==Notable trees== The largest known examples in the UK grow along Crespin Way, Hollingdean, Brighton; planted in 1964, they measured 19 m high by 50 cm d.b.h. in 2009.Johnson, O. (2011). Champion trees of Britain & Ireland, p.167. Kew Publishing, Kew London. ==Hybrid cultivars== * 'Nanguen' = , 'Clusius', 'Lobel', (all from crossings with 'Bea Schwarz' selfed), 'Amsterdam' (from an open pollination?). ==Etymology== The tree is named for Bea Schwarz, the Dutch phytopathologist who identified Dutch elm disease in the 1920s. ==Accessions== ===North America=== * Arnold Arboretum, US. Acc. nos. 151-61, 276-62 * Holden Arboretum, US. Acc. no. 57-1243 * Longwood Gardens, US. Acc. no. 1967-0876 ===Europe=== * Brighton & Hove City Council, UK. NCCPG Elm Collection. *Grange Farm Arboretum, Lincolnshire, UK. Acc. no. 1275 ==Nurseries== ===Europe=== * Noordplant , Glimmen, Netherlands. ==References== ==External links== * Sheet labelled Ulmus 'Bea Schwarz', Baarn, 1948 * Sheet labelled Ulmus 'Bea Schwarz', Baarn, 1949 *"Herbarium specimen DOV0038308".
